data.title: [Feature Request] Send text to current terminal to run
data.body:
Dear Team,

Integration with Terminal is a killing feature for VSC, and interaction between text editing and terminal would be better.
When working with VSC, I always keep both text editing window and terminal active. For example: connect to remote hive in the terminal meanwhile write some hql script in text window. Or some thing like writing python script meanwhile connect to ipython in terminal. I have to keep coping from text and pasting into terminal all the time

I think send selected text directly to current terminal maybe a better way to achieve REPL and inteactive programing.

data.title: validate ctor arguments
data.body:
re #34831

When creating an invalid relative pattern we should check the arguments throw if they are invalid, `new vscode.RelativePattern('*.ts', undefined);` or `new vscode.RelativePattern(42);`

data.title: Scrolling via mousewheel in the terminal scrolls by a lot on Windows (~12 lines)
data.body:
Testing #34868

Scrolling using the mouse wheel appears to scroll a constant number of lines, regardless of the terminal height, which can become very confusing:

[emoji-test.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1333136/emoji-test.txt)

* save this file as UTF8 with bom (I think it is already)
* configure `"terminal.integrated.scrollback": 5000`
* run `chcp 65001`
* run `cat emoji-test.txt`

This is using all the defaults:
* the editor scrolls by ~5 lines
* native PowerShell scrolls by ~3 lines
* our integrated terminal scrolls by ~12 lines

For example, in this case, scrolling via mouse wheel once has jumped over "Venezuela", which is very confusing:
![terminal-scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30861570-66a1a258-a2cb-11e7-8e65-48856c555ed8.gif)

2. Click on the big open folder button in the explorer
3. Notice that VSCode reloads - unlike most other scenarios where we are adding aditional folders where this just happens

data.title: jsdoc tweaks
data.body:
re #34831

When writing jsdoc for *classes* I usually use 'this' to refer to the object itself. So, instead of "...base file path to which the pattern will be..." use "...file path to which this pattern..."

data.title: Missing jsdoc
data.body:
re #34831

The `RelativePattern`-ctor and type-definition misses a jsdoc comment. It should outline that a relative pattern is sugar that helps to create "prefixed" patterns

data.title: Registering a FS provider with a root with an non-contributed scheme blows up explorer
data.body:
Testing #35009

1. Register a new FS provider with a root set to a URI with an unknown scheme eg `foobar:root`

Explorer doesn't render anything.

data.title: fs.existsSync fails with vscode debug tools, but works with node
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:24:39.530Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Angular-BeastCode|Mik|4.4.2
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.3
wallaby-vscode|Wal|1.0.62
yaml|ada|0.0.9
vscode-color|ans|0.4.5
python|don|0.7.0
docthis|joe|0.4.8
Angular2|joh|2.7.0
typings-autoinstaller|jvi|1.2.0
heroku-command|pko|0.0.8
vscode-icons|rob|7.14.0
vim|vsc|0.10.1
vscode-import-cost|wix|2.5.0



---
fs.existsSync fails with vscode debug tools, but works with node:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create the following js file test.js: 

    `const fs = require('fs');
    let path = 'path does not exists'; 
    console.log(fs.existsSync(path)); `
2. Run the file with node test2.js, confirm it works
3. Now run the file with the following launch.json config file:

`{
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/test2.js"
        }`

**Gives the following error:** 
`Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat 'random/address'
    at Object.fs.existsSync (fs.js:330:13)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/alexbjorlig/Documents/SolidFlow/streamRD/test2.js:4:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:621:14)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:635:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:545:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:508:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:500:3)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:665:10)
    at startup (bootstrap_node.js:201:16)
    at bootstrap_node.js:626:3`


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I tried to debug with chrome dev tools and node --inspect --debug-brk test2.js, here it works as expected.

data.title: Incorrect rendering of Thai in the integrated terminal on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #34868

* create a file `a.txt` with the following content and save it as UTF8 with BOM:
```
Thai is a Tai-Kadai language spoken by about 65 million 
people mainly in Thailand (), and also in the 
Midway Islands, Singapore, the UAE and the USA
```
* configure:
```
	"editor.fontFamily": "SimSun-ExtB",
	"terminal.integrated.fontFamily": "SimSun-ExtB"
```
* open the integrated terminal on Windows (defaults PowerShell)
* run ` chcp 65001`
* run `cat a.txt`

Observe:

* editor:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30859906-ba41d3b6-a2c5-11e7-8f98-a4885e4bf48f.png)

* native PowerShell (configured with `SimSun-ExtB` and after `chcp 65001`)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30859939-da70640e-a2c5-11e7-81e2-e9ac17c84193.png)

* ConEmu (uses cmd.exe, configured with `SimSun-ExtB` and after `chcp 65001`, with `type a.txt`):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30859982-feacc68c-a2c5-11e7-83b6-d132471d73b9.png)

* Integrated terminal in 1.13:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30860008-17e70fb8-a2c6-11e7-8b94-2bb9c79b5216.png)

* **new integrated terminal**:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30860072-2e350bd0-a2c6-11e7-948e-681e11396c5e.png)


Observe the problem around this glyph:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5047891/30860114-4f3e4256-a2c6-11e7-928e-78c7afc5493c.png)

I believe the same problem exists with Arabic, but it appears the old integrated terminal also suffered from problems with rendering Arabic (i.e. RTL).

data.title: Exclude folders for php linting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add the following to the `settings.json`:
```json
"files.exclude": {
    "**/app/cache": true
}
```
2. Have a folder opened with a php file in `app/cache` which contains invalid syntax.

The errors still shows up in the errors pane.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Issue debugging lsp-sample example
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1703)

Steps to Reproduce:

I had a few problems getting debugging working for the lsp-sample example (from the **vscode-extension-samples** repository). I'm not sure whether I am doing something wrong, so here are the steps to reproduce those issues and the changes I had to make along the way to get it working for me.

**1.** Copy **lsp-sample** directory from repository https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples

**2.** Open **lsp-sample** folder in vscode

**3.** In the integrated terminal run **npm install**

**3.** Press F5 to start the **Launch Client** debug session

**4.** Observe the error: "Could not find the preLaunchTask 'Client Watch'".

**5.** Modify launch.json preLaunchTasks to **watch:client** for **Launch Client** configuration, and **watch:server** for **Attach to Server** configuration.

**6.** Press F5 again to launch the **Launch Client** debug session.

**7.** Observe that it works this time.

**8.**  Attempt to start the **Attach to Server** debug session

**9.** Observe the error: 'Cannot connect to runtime; make sure that runtime is in 'legacy' debug mode.

**10.** Change protocol value from **legacy** to **inspector** for **Attach to Server** configuration in launch.json

**_Note_**: at this point the launch.json looks as follows:

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  // List of configurations. Add new configurations or edit existing ones.
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Launch Client",
      "type": "extensionHost",
      "request": "launch",
      "runtimeExecutable": "${execPath}",
      "args": [
        "--extensionDevelopmentPath=${workspaceRoot}/client"
      ],
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "outFiles": [
        "${workspaceRoot}/client/out/**/*.js"
      ],
      "preLaunchTask": "watch:client"
    },
    {
      "name": "Attach to Server",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "attach",
      "port": 6009,
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "outFiles": [
        "${workspaceRoot}/client/server/**/*.js"
      ],
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "preLaunchTask": "watch:server"
    }
  ]
}
```

**11.** Change _debugOptions_ line in **client/src/extension.ts** to the following:
```javascript
let debugOptions = { execArgv: ["--nolazy", "--inspect=6009"] };
```

**12.** Re-launch the **Launch Client** configuration and **Attach to Server** configuration

**13.** Observe that there are now no longer any errors and you can debug both the client and server code.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: The YUM vs-code repository is not signed.
data.body:
Trying to update code from the official yum-repository (https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode) yields the following warning message:
```
Warning: File 'repomd.xml' from repository 'Visual Studio Code' is unsigned.

    Note: Signing data enables the recipient to verify that no modifications occurred after the data
    were signed. Accepting data with no, wrong or unknown signature can lead to a corrupted system
    and in extreme cases even to a system compromise.

    Note: File 'repomd.xml' is the repositories master index file. It ensures the integrity of the
    whole repo.

    Warning: We can't verify that no one meddled with this file, so it might not be trustworthy
    anymore! You should not continue unless you know it's safe.
```

As the warning states, signatures are important for integrity and trust.
So while I am aware that the packages and the manifest are transmitted via an encrypted channel, the warning may discourage users from updating or installing vs code.

data.title: Allow to specify file path preferences for Copy path of Active File command
data.body:
This is a feature request. It would be nice if user could specify the following things in preferences for paths that are copied to clipboard when you use "Copy path of Active File" command:

- *separators type*: Windows style i.e. backwards slashes or Unix style - i.e. normal slashes. 
- *base*: currently paths begin from file system root (e.g. C:\Users\...). It would be nice to specify that when you are copying paths to clipboard you want it to start from project folder root or from a folder where git repository is based.

Use case:
=====

I'm on Windows. I use VCS, namely git, from integrated terminal. When I want to perform git commands on opened files (like for example `git blame` ) I have to get hold of file path. But git expects file paths to start from project root, not from File system root. It also only understands normal slashes. So now every time I want to do simple git blame or git log on a certain file I have to do a lot of work:

1. Copy file path
2. Insert it somewhere in the opened editor
3. Open "Replace" command
4. Replace all occurances of "\\" to "/"
5. Select part of the path that starts from project root folder and copy it to cpipboard
6. Return focus to terminal and insert my file path

I have to do quite a lot of this during my day, and honestly it isn't much fun.
